audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Books for Unit 5 and Unit 6.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 5 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Bee and Daisy.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Listen to the sound.

This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long i (tie)>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ī/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long i sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/biiit/, bit. /bīīīt/, bite. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about animal activity. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. mule deer <pause>, porcupine <pause>, wild rabbit <pause>, coyote. Look at the picture of the porcupine. What do you notice about this animal?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about animal activity. The word is observations. Observations are notes about things you see and hear around you.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, observations>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, investigate>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Animal Activity.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words observations and investigate>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about animal activity? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 6 Student Book. The title of this story is "By the Light of the Moon.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: By the Light of the Moon. This story is fiction. It has animal characters who talk and behave like people.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: observe. To observe something is to carefully watch it. The cats observe a small bug climbing up the wall. Which tools can you use to observe things up close?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, supply>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that identifies the animals in the story.
What does the young mouse observe about the moon? Find the sentence that answers the question.
The young mice want to fly to the moon and bring back cheese for their friends. What does this tell you about them?
If you had the chance to fly to the moon, would you go? Why or why not?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about what it would be like to have a feast with your friends. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.
Total Slides

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Oral Blending and Segmenting Words with Final Blends

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the story “By the Light of the Moon.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Oral Blending and Segmenting Words with Final Blends

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following sounds: /l/ /a/ /s/ /t/.
Repeat the sounds and blend them to make a word. /lllaaassst/, last.
Now listen as your teacher says the following sounds. Blend them together to make a word.
Now let's segment a word into sounds. Listen as I say a word: last
Repeat the word and tap each sound as you say it. /l/ /a/ /s/ /t/
Now listen as your teacher says the following words. Say each word. Then say each word again as you tap each sound as you say it.

This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long I (tie)>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ī/ sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long i sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/biiit/, bit. /bīīīt/, bite. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: good, many, near, off, people.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word many. Say the word with me. Many. Which sounds do you hear in many? /m/ /e/ /n/ /ē/. Blend the sounds together.
Spell the word with me: m-a-n-y. The word "many" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: good, near, off, people.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a story about darkness and sunlight. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. sun <pause>, light <pause>, opposum <pause>, fox <pause>, buzzard <pause>, spider <pause>, darkness <pause>, bowl. Look at the spider in the picture. What is the spider doing?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about darkness and sunlight. The word is bewildered. Bewildered means confused or uncertain.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, bewildered>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the wordand predicament>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Grandmother Spider and the Sun.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words bewildered and predicament>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about darkness and sunlight? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 14 Student Book. The title of this text is "The Rot Race.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Rot Race. This text is about observing fresh foods spoiling over time and growing mold.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: contaminated. Contaminated is something that has been made harmful or poisonous. The stream was contaminated with chemicals from the nearby factory. How do you know if food is safe to eat? How can you tell if it is contaminated?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, goods>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the phrase that tells the purpose of the Rot Race.
What should you do with the contaminated food after the experiment? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why do you think that some food has more mold than other foods? Use details from the text to explain.
Have you ever eaten blue cheese? What did it taste like? If you haven’t eaten it, would you like to try it?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a list of three to five facts you learned about food sppiling and growing mold. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
Total Slides

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Creatures of the Dawn and Dusk.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card (tie) for Long i>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ī/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the long i sound, let’s blend some words using this sound and other sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with igh.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with long i spelled y.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word kit. <pause> Add the letter e after t. What word did you make? Kite
audio.notes: <visual: show letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word kit<pause>. Now change kit to kite. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Read the sentences to a partner. Switch roles once partner one has finished.
Write a sentence using the word pie. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pie>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: flight/sky, why/like.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs flight/sky, why/like>

audio.transcription: Total Slides

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.

Let's review syllable types. We know that words are made up of syllables. For example, the words "insect," "paper" and "raisin" each have two syllables. Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words.
Closed syllables are syllables that have a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants.
The word "insect" has two closed syllalbles: "in" <pause> "sect."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word insect broken up into two cards: in-sect>

audio.transcription: Open syllables are syllables that end in a vowel and have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before and after the consonant.
The word "paper" has one open syllable: "pa" <pause> and one closed syllable: "per."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word paper broken up into two cards: pa-per>

audio.transcription: Vowel team syllables are syllables that contain a vowel team. The vowel team stays together in the same syllable.
The word "raisin" has one vowel team syllable: "rai" <pause> "sin"
audio.notes: <visual: show the word raisin broken up into two cards: rai-sin>

audio.transcription: Practice identifying the different syllable types in the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: plastic, minus, menu, explain>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long (tie)i>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: very, right, that, two, under>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word very. Say the word with me. Very. The word "very" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: v-e-r-y. The letter "y" makes the /ē/ sound in the word "very."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: right, that, two, under.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word my.
Now write the word twice.
Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
lit
lift
life
kind
kindly

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 6 Student Book. The title of this story is "A Firefly Surprise." Point to each word as you read the title with me: A Firefly Surprise. This is a comic. pay careful attention to both the illustrations and the words in the speech bubbles. Read the comic. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and poem>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the comic with long i spellings and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: Did you find a dime under the desk? Say the sentence with me: Did you find a dime under the desk? Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.
The second sentence is: A very bright light shines on the stage. Say the sentence with me: A very bright light shines on the stage. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Total Slides
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the story “A Firefly Surprise.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Let's review syllables. The words "attic," "focus," and "delight" each have two syllables. Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words.
When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants. The word "attic" has two closed syllables: "at" <pause> "tic" <pause> "attic."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word attic broken up into two cards: at-tic>

audio.transcription: When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before and after the consonant. The word "focus" has one open syllable "fo" and one closed syllable "cus." "fo" <pause> "cus" <pause> "focus."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word focus broken up into two cards: fo-cus>

audio.transcription: The word "delight" has one open syllable "de" and one closed syllable "light." "de" <pause> "light" <pause> "delight."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word delight broken up into two cards: de-light>

audio.transcription: Practice dividing the following words into syllables.

Look at these words. Let's read the words together: flying, slide, sight, smile, inside, high, myself, flashlight, spy, nice. Now look at these three spelling patterns for the long i sound: i-g-h, i-consonant-e, and y. This is the word flying. Read the word with me. <pause> Which pattern should I put flying under? <pause> Yes, flying goes in the y category because the word contains the letter y. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words sleep, cheat, meat, deep, heat, keep> <visual: show word sleep> <visual: show the sorting cards ee and ea in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
i-g-h, i-consonant-e, and y are common spelling patterns. You may notice these spelling patterns in many words. As we read, let's look for words with i-g-h, i-consonant-e, and y.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about creatures in the deep ocean. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. vampire squid <pause>, deep-sea anglerfish <pause>, barreleye fish <pause>, Goblin shark. Look at the picture of the barreleye fish. Where might this creature live?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about creatures in the deep ocean. The word is detect. Detect means to spot or become aware of something.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, detect>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, transparent,>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Life in the Midnight Zone.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words, detect and transparent,>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about creatures in the deep ocean? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 6 Student Book. The title of this text is "Lights in the Deep.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Lights in the Deep. You will read about different sea animals that make their own light.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: attract. To attract is to draw something near. Flowers use their scent, or smell, to attract bees to them. What can attract bugs to a picnic?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, attract>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that tells what part of an anglerfish attracts other fish.
How does the vampire squid protect itself? Find the sentences that answer this question.
Why is it important for these animals to make their own light? Explain.
Which of these animals do you find the most interesting? Why?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. Write an important fact about each fish in each box. <pause> Use these facts to write a one or two sentence summary of the text. Share your ideas with a partner before you write.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Sounds (Parts of Blends in the Final Position)

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Lights in the Deep” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Sounds (Parts of Blends in the Final Position)

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: brand
Say the word brand, but change /d/ to /ch/. What's the new word? <pause> branch
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the second sound in a word. Listen as I say a word: glue
Say the word glue, but change /l/ to /r/. What's the new word? <pause> grew
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show sound-spelling card for long i (tie)>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ī/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: good, many, near, off, people, right, that, two, under, very.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word good. Say the word with me: "good"
Spell the word with me: g-o-o-d. Say the word with me. After. Which sounds do you hear in after? /g/ /o͝o/ /d/ . Blend the sounds together.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: many, near, off, people, right, that, two, under, very.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with long i and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with long i. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word sunlight. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word sunlight>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: my/drive, kind/invite.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs my/drive, kind/invite.>

audio.transcription: Total Slides
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long i>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ī/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: many, good, near, off, people, right, that, two, under, very.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word many. Say the word with me: "many"
Spell the word with me: m-a-n-y. The word "many" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: good, near, off, people, right, that, two, under, very.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. good, <pause> many, <pause> near, <pause> off, <pause> people, <pause> right, <pause> that, <pause> two, <pause> under, <pause> very.
audio.notes: <visual: show "good, many, near, off, people, right, that, two, under, very" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "I am a good friend because ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "I am a good friend because [blank]." Then show "good, many, near, off, people, right, that, two, under, very" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 6 Student Book. The title of this text is "Ocean Zones." Point to the word as you read the title with me: Ocean Zones. This is a functional text about ocean zones. The author includes a paragraph about each zone at the top. The diagram below shows how deep each zone is and which animals live there. In order to understand the text, we must think carefully about how the words and pictures connect.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the diagram?
Draw one of the ocean zones described in the functional text and label the different animals found in that zone.
Total Slides

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Ocean Zones.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Let's review syllable types. We know that words are made up of syllables. For example, the words "tennis," "silent," and "beneath" each have two syllables. Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words.
Closed syllables are syllables that have a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants.
The word "tennis" has two closed syllalbles: "ten" <pause> "nis."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word tennis broken up into two syllables: ten-nis>

audio.transcription: Open syllables are syllables that end in a vowel and have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before and after the consonant.
The word "silent" has one open syllable: "si" and one closed syllable: "lent."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word silent broken up into two cards: si-lent>

audio.transcription: Vowel team syllables are syllables that contain a vowel team. Vowel team always stays together in the same syllable.
The word "beneath" has one vowel team syllable: "be" <pause> "neath."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word beneath broken up into two syllables: be-neath>

audio.transcription: Practice identifying the different syllable types in the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: frantic, final, comic, upright>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long I (tie)>

audio.transcription: Write each spelling several times. Say the /ī/ sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with igh.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with ind or ild.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word fin. <pause> Add the letter d after n. What word did you make? Find.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the e-pocket chart and letter cards so the teacher can model this.>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word fin <pause>. Now change fin to find. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about different kinds of ice skates. First, look at these three pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. hockey player <pause>, hockey stick <pause>, blade <pause>, helmet <pause>, speed skater <pause>, figure skater. Look at the pictures of the hockey player, speed skater, and figure skater. What is each person wearing?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about different kinds of ice skates. The word is maneuver. Maneuver means to change direction and position for a specific purpose.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, maneuver>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, distribute>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Time to Hit the Ice.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words maneuver and distribute>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about different kinds of ice skates? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 6 Student Book. The title of this story is "Mice on Ice.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Mice on Ice. You will read a story about a boy who finds a surprising sight.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: witness. To witness is to see something yourself. Pedro and Lucy witness a kite flying over the park. What is something you would like to witness?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, confront>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find how many mice live under the floor.
What does Kyle witness in the kitchen? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why are the mice frightened? Explain.
What would you do if you saw mice ice skating in your freezer? Would you react the same way that Kyle did?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four pictures to remember the important details in the text. Label the details, such as Kyle, mice, freezer, skating, pie. <pause> Use your drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.
Total Slides
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Mice on Ice.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

This is the sound-spelling card for long i. The "i-e," "i," "igh," "y" and "i consonant e" spellings stand for the long i sound. What sound does the "i-e" spelling make in the word "tie?" <pause> /ī/. Listen as your teacher continues with more long i spellings and words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for Long i>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word price.
Now write the word drying.
Finally, write this sentence: We fly two kites near the wide path.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about fireflies. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. firefly <pause>, abdomen <pause>, tree <pause>, woods <pause>, grass <pause>, nighttime. Look at the woods in the picture. What do you notice about the woods?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about fireflies. The word is gather. When people gather, they come together in the same place.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, gather>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
Now listen to “Lighting Up the Night.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words gather and momentarily>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about fireflies? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 6 Student Book. The title of this story is "Firefly Tricks Spider.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Firefly Tricks Spider. This is a story about insects that speak and act like humans.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: devious. To be devious is to not be honest. The devious troll tricked the man into giving up his gold. Which characters from books, movies, or TV shows would you describe as devious? Why?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, favor>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word in the story that tells when Spider spins her web.
Why does Firefly think that Spider’s actions are unfair? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How are Firefly and Spider alike? How are they different?
Do you think Spider will change her devious ways? Why or why not?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write about how Spider reacts to the arrival of the fireflies. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write.
Total Slides

toc.title: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 6, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need…your Student Book for Unit 6.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 6 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Firefly Tricks Spider.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: high-way
Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. high-way, highway.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: backpack
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Backpack, back-pack.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

Let's review syllables. The words "absent," "siren," and "railway" each have two syllables. Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words.
When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants. The word "absent" has two closed syllables: "ab" <pause> "sent" <pause> "absent."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word absent broken up into two cards: ab-sent>

audio.transcription: When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before and after the consonant. The word "siren" has one open syllable "si" and one closed syllable "ren." "si" <pause> "ren" <pause> "siren."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word siren broken up into two cards: si-ren>

audio.transcription: The word "railway" has two closed syllables: "rail" <pause> "way" <pause> "railway."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word railway broken up into two cards: rail-way>

audio.transcription: Practice dividing the following words into syllables.
Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
This word names something that rings.
Change one letter in bell to name a piece of paper money.
Change one letter in bill to name a raised area of land.
Remove two letters from hill to form a word that is short for hello.
Add two letters to hi to make the opposite of low
Add one letter to high to name a part of your leg.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: good, many, near, off, people, right, that, two, under, very>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "near."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: near>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 6!
Total Slides
